description: From be- (“about, around”) +‎ labour. Compare bework, betoil, beswink.

verbs.description: belabour (third-person singular simple present belabours, present participle belabouring, simple past and past participle belaboured)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To labour about; labour over; work hard upon; ply diligently.
(British spelling, transitive) To beat soundly; thump; beat someone.
examples: He saw the village; he was seen coming bending forward upon his horse, belabouring it with great blows, the girths dripping with blood.

entries.meaning: (British spelling, transitive) To attack someone verbally.
(British spelling, transitive) To discuss something unduly or repeatedly; to harp on.
examples: Let both sides explore what problems unite us instead of belabouring those problems which divide us.

entries.meaning: (British spelling, transitive) To explain or elaborate at length or in excessive detail; overelaborate.
